results.title: Cyclone Tracy
results.creator_credit: Chris Noonan, Peter Johnson, Timothy Read and Film Australia
results.brief_description: At Christmas 1974, Darwin was hit by Cyclone Tracy, which left a train of almost inconceivable destruction. This film shows the damage wrought, and people’s reactions during and after the cyclone.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Chris Noonan, Peter Johnson, Timothy Read and Film Australia
results.description: At Christmas 1974, Darwin was hit by Cyclone Tracy, which left a train of almost inconceivable destruction. This film shows the damage wrought, and people’s reactions during and after the cyclone.

results.title: Cyclone approaching
results.creator_credit: Cecil Holmes, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Indicates the counter-disaster operations initiated by the civil defence organizations and the simple safety procedures which should be followed by the community in general. Uses Cyclone Tracy as an example and includes graphic scenes depicting the type of devastation that cyclones can produce.

results.title: Cupid's complaint
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian Road Safety Council
results.brief_description: A rather solidly-built Cupid complains to his mother that he had picked out a beautifully matched couple and was bringing them together, but now, as a result of the girl not giving hand signals and the young man speeding, they have crashed into one another’s cars and are furious with each other.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian Road Safety Council

results.title: Crocodile hunters
results.creator_credit: Lee Robinson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: In the rivers and billabongs of Northern Territory small fresh-water crocodiles are traditionally hunted using spear and canoe. But, in recent years, a new industry has become established in these regions - the hunting of the crocodile for his skin, which brings a high price in the south when manufactured into hand-bags, shoes, wallets and ornaments. Teams of hunters make their camps by the rivers and estuaries where fresh-water and salt-water varieties are found. Photography by Frank Bagnall.

results.title: Cooee
results.creator_credit: Graham Chase, Geoffrey Barnes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: In 1915, the Australian Land Army marched on the Cooee trail from the mid-western farming town of Gilgandra to Sydney, gathering volunteer troops for the Dardanelles on the way. In 1987, a new band of “Cooees” set off to re-enact the march. The film’s production crew were involved from the march’s planning stage. This record of the re-enactment covering the 550 km from Gilgandra to the Sydney Town Hall not only provides a portrait of the individuals involved but also gives a glimpse of the mood and attitudes of rural Australia, 1987.

results.title: The Computer Centre
results.creator_credit: Peter Weir, Joe Scully and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Adults Learning”.
A teaching aid to promote group discussion on the apprehension adults feel in adapting to computer technology. Shows a group of trainees being taught the operation of punch cards as part of a session in the use of computers.

results.title: City in the sun
results.creator_credit: Alasdair Loch and Australian news and Information Bureau
results.brief_description: Inspired by Arne Sucksdorff’s “Manniskor i Stad” (Rhythm of a city), this film reflects the mood of a day in the life of Sydney, New South Wales, from morning until night.

results.title: Citizen soldier
results.creator_credit: Greg Reading, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Telemark Productions
results.brief_description: An impression of the life throughout the year of a citizen soldier in the Citizens Military Forces. It delves into such aspects as how effective CMF training really is, why it is important to the individual and the country and what it offers to the soldier and to his employer.

results.title: The Change at Groote
results.creator_credit: Stefan Sargent, Richard Mason and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Designed to show how the aboriginal people of Groote Eylandt in the Gulf of Carpentaria are adjusting to the new life brought about by the discovery on their lands of vast manganese deposits which are now being mined by Broken Hill Proprietary. Made as a fragmented collage of images and sounds, it is intended to produce a direct emotional response, and suggest the confused values of the aboriginals undergoing a social and cultural revolution.
